Overview

One of the products I'm most proud of designing is a desktop app initially called WinAutomation from Softomotive.

I was the principal designer on the project, responsible for everything from user research to iterated UI/UX design in a truly agile (meaning that we abided by all the rituals) team of seven.

I conducted internal user testing and feedback sessions throughout the design process to ensure the app met the needs of our target audience. On the process, the app was acquired by Microsoft and is now included in Windows 11 with its new name, Power Automate Desktop or PAD for short.

PAD is a low-code desktop automation solution that allows users to free up time and focus on things that really matter. Its key highlights:

1

Automates repetitive tasks

2

Enhances productivity

3

Integrates multiple systems

 

Problems

Prior to its transformation into PAD, the product was known as WinAutomation and was under the ownership of Softomotive.

Upon joining the team, I encountered three primary challenges with the product:

1

It was dated

A visually outdated and disconnected design was observed by everyone

2

It was hard to use

A shift towards simplified user journeys for a wider user base was needed

3

It was not accessible

Inclusive design is paramount for users with various limitations

Opportunity

"How can we provide effective support to a large audience in automating their repetitive workflows by offering a modern and user-friendly tool?"

User persona

To gain a deeper understanding of our users, I crafted a persona that allowed us to empathize and connect with their needs and experiences on a more personal level.

Execute without oversight

"I'm tired of spending hours on end doing the same monotonous tasks on my computer."

Boost productivity

"The repetitive nature of these tasks drains my energy and leaves me feeling unproductive and frustrated."

Methodical at work

"I'm motivated to find a way to automate these repetitive tasks, freeing up my time and allowing me to focus on more important work."

Automate workflows

"I yearn for a solution that simplifies these repetitive tasks, bringing ease and efficiency into my daily workflow."

Failing to meet OKRs

"The lack of automation options makes me feel like I'm wasting valuable resources and potential."

Design goals

The design process for WinAutomation commenced with thorough internal research. I engaged in discussions with key stakeholders, including designers, developers, managers, the CTO and the CEO.

My primary focus was on customer care representatives who had valuable first-hand insights into user experiences. Additionally, I collaborated closely with tech writers who had been writing help page articles to further understand user needs and pain points.

After gathering all the necessary information, the head of design, product manager, and I collaborated to meticulously subcategorize the tasks into four main categories that I worked on as a the principal designer.

UI design4

UX improvements3

Accessibility3

Design system4

UI redesign

When I undertook the UI facelift of the app (in 2019), it was still sporting a skeuomorphic design style reminiscent of the mid-2000s.

We embarked on a transformational journey by introducing colors, updating the icons into with a contemporary flat style, enhancing layouts and incorporating helpful illustrations.

Curious about details? Dive a little deeper

Users opens VM

Select use case

Power Automate Desktop (after)

Users opens VM

Select use case

UX improvements

Throughout the project, I maintained open communication with stakeholders, involved developers early in the process.

Moreover, I tried to keep consistency with existing patterns that hundreds of users had grown accustomed to while making both minor and major improvements to enhance overall user experience.

Finally, as a team we placed great emphasis on accessibility and I conducted regular design QA (quality assurance) checks to ensure optimal usability.

1. User research

I conducted user research to gain insights through internal interviews

2. Defined objectives

I clearly defined the objectives of the UX & UI improvements based on feedback and business priorities

3. Information architecture

I assessed the app's UX flows and identified opportunities to simplify them

4. Wireframing & prototyping

I created wireframes and interactive mockups to validate design ideas, with feedback from stakeholders

5. Iterative design

Incorporating feedback I iterated on the mockups and prototypes to refine the user experience

6. Usability testing

I conducted usability testing sessions to identify further areas for refinement

Accessibility

Why it matters

Every human on the planet approaches situations differently.

We all have different ways to think about problems, different things we need to make decisions and different ways we like to learn.

— Cambridge Cognition

Design system

When I joined WinAutomation, there was no established design system in place. Although the team had intentions to creating one, we had been preoccupied with other priorities.

One of my responsibilities was to initiate the process by carefully analyzing the existing patterns and compiling an inventory of design assets and components across the entire Softomotive product family.

Just as I began the componentization process, the company underwent acquisition by Microsoft. Consequently, I shifted gears and transitioned to utilizing Microsoft's renowned Fluent design system, aligning our efforts with their established framework.

Project launch results

Starting with a closed circle of beta testers, we verified that we had successfully achieved all the project goals. We made it modern and highly user-friendly.

From there on, since its acquisition by Microsoft, the app's user reach grew exponentially. As part of the Power Automate family (which allows other parts of Microsoft Office and more automation) it offers a lot more than originally anticipated.

Since it’s included in Windows 11, it’s attracting millions of users worldwide who rely on it to save time and prioritize their core tasks.

The business impact was huge and can be seen by the peer reviews it has received.

4.6 out of 5

349 reviews

4.4 out of 5

137 ratings

8.4 out of 10

185 ratings

4.4 out of 5

149 reviews

4.0 out of 5

50 reviews

Key takeaways

Effective collaboration: The project's success hinged on seamless collaboration among individuals from diverse teams and locations, navigating time zone differences and fostering a shared vision.

Clear communication: Open and effective communication channels were essential to ensure everyone was aligned and felt productive in a cohesive working environment.

Adaptability to change: The acquisition of the company introduced new systems and processes, requiring the team to quickly adapt and embrace change, leveraging it as an opportunity for growth.

Humility and teamwork: A low-ego approach and a strong focus on teamwork allowed for the sharing of ideas, constructive feedback and a collective commitment to achieving the project's objectives.

Continuous improvement: Regular retrospective rituals provided valuable insights for refining workflows, identifying areas for improvement, and implementing adjustments to enhance future projects.

NEXT STEPS
The journey of Power Automate Desktop is an ongoing one, marked by continuous growth and endless possibilities.

By harnessing the power of Chat GPT's technology across our product lineup, we have revolutionized the ease of building natural language-based automations.
